messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 6/8/2003 12:36:15 PM Central Daylight Time,
swords@... writes:

> Thanks Milt but I must admit it sure looks like a single antler. Of course
> I never could tell a tree from an antler on the ground.
>
> Ron
> STL
>

Ron,
Nothing is 100%.....yours may be an antler.
I posted a pic of my tsuba in the list album. If you look at the silhouette,
you will notice they are identical except they are not, yours is maple und
mine is peach.

Milt

Ron

----- Original Message -----
From: MuramasaIII@...
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, June 07, 2003 2:32 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] maple leaves/deer horn motif


In a message dated 6/7/2003 1:29:16 PM Central Daylight Time,
swords@... writes:

> A tsuba I've got on Ebay right now--Kyo-Shoami, most likely--has the motif
> of "maple leaves and a deer antler" represented on it. Somebody just asked
> me about the meaning of this design and I realized, I have no idea. Can any
> of you comment on what this motif represents

Ron,
It's NOT a deer horn, if you look closer you will see it's part of the tree
trunk/branch.
I know because I have an almost identical one except mine is a peach
tree...........

Milt

messages.subject: Re: maple leaves/deer horn motif
messages.msgSnippet: Ron - There is a nearly identical one listed in one of the Haynes catalogs as maple leaves and deer horn. It doesn t give a meaning. Rich ... Richard Stein,
messages.messageBody:
Ron -

There is a nearly identical one listed in one of the
Haynes catalogs as maple leaves and deer horn. It doesn't
give a meaning.

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] maple leaves/deer horn motif
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron, I haven t handled that tsuba, but Kyo Shoami seems like a good call.  I don t think I ve seen one lacquered like that before. Deer and maple leaves are
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron,
I haven't handled that tsuba, but Kyo Shoami seems like a good call. I don't think I've seen one lacquered like that before.

Deer and maple leaves are a fairly common autumn motif. More specifically deer are associated with one of the principle deities at Kasuga jinja in Nara. There are a lot of deer at Kasuga shrine and elsewhere in Nara that are rounded up in the fall to have their antlers sawn off. So, I think that the antler with the maple branches and leaves was intended to evoke Kasuga jinja in particular, the hills around Nara and autumn in general.

I checked Google for Kasuga jinja links - this site touches on the deer:
http://fischer.jinkan.kyoto-u.ac.jp/soramitsu/DivineDeer.html

Milt, I think that it is an antler at the bottom left (looking at the front view) below the kozuka ana. The rest are maple branches.
Jim




Hi Jim, group -

A tsuba I've got on Ebay right now--Kyo-Shoami, most likely--has the motif of "maple leaves and a deer antler" represented on it. Somebody just asked me about the meaning of this design and I realized, I have no idea. Can any of you comment on what this motif represents?

http://tinyurl.com/dpws

Also, I've always found it curious to have the remnants of lacquer remaining on the leaves. Jim, you might have handles this tsuba awhile back when we last talked, I'm not sure. Interesting to see this treatment. Comments welcomed!

Ron
STL



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
